channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Cost of huge CCTV combined network sees Auckland Council pull out
item.description: Auckland Council has pulled out of a plan to expand the city's network of CCTV cameras because it would have cost too much.

item.title: Japanese rescue crews find another survivor from missing freighter
item.description: Japanese rescue crews have found another survivor from a live export ship that sank off the country's south-west on Wednesday.

item.title: Aucklanders react to news they'll be staying in alert level 2.5
item.description: "It is what it is" was the overwhelming sentiment on the streets today, as Aucklanders digested news of at least another 12 days at alert level 2.5.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 4 September
item.description: New Zealand has its first death in months, Ardern announces restrictions will stay the same for now, and her Aussie counterpart hints at a travel bubble.

item.title: Man dies from Covid-19 in Middlemore Hospital
item.description: A man in his 50s linked to the Auckland cluster has died at Middlemore Hospital today, bringing the country's death toll to 23.

item.title: Mt Eden bones: Residents not surprised at identity of man entombed in concrete
item.description: The owner of the house beneath which human remains were found says it's good to have the identity of the dead man confirmed. Meanwhile, police are continuing to investigate old links.

item.title: Rocket Lab reveals successful secret launch of rocket satellite 'Photon'
item.description: A transforming rocket satellite - a proof-of-concept design - has successfully launched from New Zealand's Mahia Peninsula, Rocket Lab says.

item.title: Invercargill city councillors spend day in crisis talks after Department of Internal Affairs' concerns raised
item.description: Invercargill city councillors have spent most of an extraordinary meeting behind closed doors talking about how they plan to restore the public's trust and confidence.

item.title: Covid-19: Auckland to remain at alert level 2.5 until at least 16 September - Ardern
item.description: Auckland will remain at alert level 2.5 for more than another week, the prime minister has confirmed. Watch the latest media conference here.

item.title: Covid-19 update: Five new cases in New Zealand - three community cases, two imported
item.description: There have been five new cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today - three in the community and two imported, Director General of Health Ashley Bloomfield has revealed.

item.title: Missing cattle export ship: Second survivor dies
item.description: A second survivor of the livestock vessel that disappeared in the East China Sea has died.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates for 4 September
item.description: There is still a risk of spread of Covid-19 to other parts of the country, which is a good reason to maintain the rest of the country on alert level 2, the PM says. See how the rest of the day unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Vote to continue commercial pheasant preserves ruffles feathers
item.description: A vote by the National Fish and Game Council to allow commercial pheasant preserves to continue operating, despite contrary legal advice from Sir Geoffrey Palmer, has divided the hunting community.

item.title: Lime's e-scooters back on the streets of Auckland - this time under the Jump brand
item.description: Lime is back operating e-scooters in Auckland after buying Jump's business from Uber and receiving operating permits from the city's council.

item.title: Maritime NZ reports no issues found with Gulf Livestock 1 before it sailed
item.description: Maritime New Zealand said the vessel was checked on arrival and prior to departure from Napier, and no irregularities were found.

item.title: Principals want lockdown rules changed for exams
item.description: Some secondary school principals want the government to change its alert level rules to ensure NCEA and Scholarship exams can go ahead during a lockdown.

item.title: Sawmill fined nearly quarter million dollars after worker lost three fingers
item.description: A timber company in Taranaki has been fined nearly a quarter of a million dollars after a worker lost three fingers and part of his palm clearing unguarded machinery.

item.title: Woman unable to receive Covid relief due to casual work
item.description: A Nelson woman is furious with Work and Income that her efforts to support herself while being made redundant because of Covid-19 have left her financially worse off.
